content:
Unless there is something wrong with your system, Thunderbird will reopen with the same tabs it had last time it was open.

The things wrong are usually antivirus products that overreach and system optimization tools like CCleaner which actually cripples Thunderbird in the name of "protecting you"
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I am asked repetitively to allow Mozilla to access my Google account, because giving my consent is useless.

I'm not sure what you're trying to tell here. Giving permission for Thunderbird to access your Gmail account is part of the OAuth authentication process. You won't be able to access your account via Thunderbird without giving permission.

For the authentication to work you'll have to allow cookies in Thunderbird. Also see 

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/automatic-conversion-google-mail-accounts-oauth20
creator: christ1

content: I had to change my Google password. Immediately after the change, I was and am still unable to send or receive mails, receiving the message : "Authentication failed when connecting to imap.gmail.com server". Giving my permission/consent to allow Mozilla accessing my Google account is useless, because it is repetetively asking me to note my password in " imap.gmail.com" but I don't know how to do. Do you have a solution ? Many thanks
creator: patrick.guerisse

content: And I have allowed cookies in Thunderbird.
creator: patrick.guerisse

content:
Giving my permission/consent to allow Mozilla accessing my Google account is useless, because it is repetetively asking me to note my password

I'm sorry, but I don't understand what you're trying to say. What exactly does 'note my password' mean?

Can you login to your account via webmail?

Note, when using OAuth authentication, you'll have to use your main Google account password, not an app password you may have created at some point.
creator: christ1

content:
Più che crittografate sembrano danneggiate. Verifica anzitutto che non sia stato l'antivirus ad intervenire sugli archivi di Thunderbird (controlla il suo LOG).

Poi eventualmente segui questa procedura:

  1. Fai un backup -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo
  2. Compatta le cartelle -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/compattazione-cartelle
  3. Riavvia Thunderbird
  4. Se il problema non è risolto, rigenera l'indice globale -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/ricostruzione-indice-globale
  5. Riavvia Thunderbird
  6. Se il problema non si è ancora risolto: click destro sulla cartella che contiene la mail illeggibile -> Proprietà -> [Ripara la cartella]
creator: @next

  2. also, rightclick on a local folder, click properties and see where it says it is located

content: What version of Thunderbird? What is your account Type - POP or IMAP? What is your anti-virus software?
creator: christ1

content:
Please respond to your support forum topic.

Version 128.2.0esr IMAP Panda Dome

You most likely experience the folder corruption problem described in this bug. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1890230

Try to repair the affected folder(s). Right-click the folder - Properties - Repair Folder

Wrt anti-virus software, it is recommended to create an exception in your anti-virus software for the Thunderbird profile folder, so that the anti-virus real-time scanner will not scan it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-to-find-your-profile
creator: christ1

content: You might experiment with setting a manual filter to locate messages older than 30 days and move them that way.
creator: davidsk

content:
david said
You might experiment with setting a manual filter to locate messages older than 30 days and move them that way.

Unfortunately I don't think this will work. The filter rules don't have an "archive" action, and the destination archive folder is going to be dependent on the current source folder.
creator: user130953890299920595695291845349334830050

content: I think it may still have merit for experimentation. Each filter is focused on one account and the selected messages could be moved to archive.
creator: davidsk

content:
david said
I think it may still have merit for experimentation. Each filter is focused on one account and the selected messages could be moved to archive.

I have indeed experimented. The filter is account based, but we are talking folder-level here. The messages in each folder must be moved to the corresponding folder in the local archives folder.

If you believe this is achievable, please outline the exact specification of the filter rule, because based on my own experiments, no such facility exists within the current mail filter rule configuration.
creator: user130953890299920595695291845349334830050

content:
Ok, I confess to not having a true solution, as I've never seen this issue. If I were to try this, my approach would be to:

  1. set the archive option for account to preserve existing structure and save in Local Folders
  2. create a search folder for the account for messages older than 30 days
  3. run the search and save the results
  4. highlight the list of results and click 'archive' - each message should be stored in like-named archive folder.

I did a small test and it worked for me.
creator: davidsk

content:
david said

  1. create a search folder for the account for messages older than 30 days

I didn't know about the "Saved Search" facility, but this works great for collating emails for archiving. Thank you very much for the help.

content: I was glad to help. Funny. I didn't know about setting archive to preserve folder structure until you posted your question. :) so we both benefited.  :)

content: If the new server will not have the messages, you need to download everything you want saved. If POP, you already have the messages on your PC. If IMAP, I suggest 1) checking the synchronization&storage section to confirm the desired folders are authorized for download, and 2) click file>offline>downlload to ensure that all messages, not just headers are downloaded. Next, copy the folders to Local Folders to ensure not losing the messages. Only after doing that would you close the old account. And, be sure to do backups afterwards.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thank you for the response. That would keep the messages, which is basically what I have done, but I want all the messages for a particular email to be displayed, from the old and the new server. The question is then, how do I stop Thunderbird "syncing", all I want it to do is to download messages that are not on the local machine, I don't want it to delete messages from the machine that are not on the server, nor to delete messages from the server that are not on the machine, I don't want it to delete anything, that is why I ticked the choice not to delete anything. Obviously my understanding of what that does is not Thunderbird's :)

Outlook Express did just what was needed in 1998, the last 22 years I have only used webmail, and started using Thunderbird beginning of this year as I need the emails on the machine.
creator: Sangoma

content:
I think the only way is for me to change to POP, download all from the old server, then change the connection details to the new server also using POP, then I should retain the messages from the old server and the messages from the new server will just add on to those already there.

Means creating lots of new accounts, as you can't change the server type.
creator: Sangoma

content: Downloading IMAP as I suggested accomplishes the same as setting up a POP account. The download from IMAP does not duplicate anything; it just ensures that all messages are saved. Unless I misunderstood, there is nothing else to do for the old account, since you have the downloaded messages and can save them in Local Folders.
creator: davidsk

content: If I have them saved in local folders, can I then view them in the "new" mailbox (same email address but on another server) along with the new messages that will come in to the new server? As I understand it, and what happened to me was that as soon as I refreshed from the new server, all the old emails previously downloaded from the old server were deleted because they do not exist on the new server.
creator: Sangoma

content: It seem you have an IMAP account. IMAP accounts have messages on the server, providing a copy on PC, but the sync process does as you say, keeping the PC in line with the server. You can keep the old messages in Local Folders and read and reply from there. If you want them as part of the account's inbox, you would need to upload them to the inbox, a problematic venture that does not always work. To do it, I suggest uploading small groups at a time.
creator: davidsk

content: Yes, that is exactly it, I thought the IMAP was indicated in my first post. However creating new POP accounts on the old server, downloading all the mail from the old server, then editing the server setup of the account to the new server works just fine. All emails old and new are then in the same place. Setting the leave message on server until I delete and backing up the whole mail folder automatically will keep things safely, and will also mean that if I ever want to change my hosting and email again, I won't have the same problem. This will work for me as I only use a PC for email, I don't look at it on any other devices, and for others they can use webmail on portable devices for new mail after the change over, old mail they would have to check on their PCs, a minor inconvenience, which will grow less as time moves on.
creator: Sangoma

content: Settings/General/Language & Appearance, 'Hide system window titlebar'.

If I change this setting in Properties and click "Apply" it will revert back to the blacked out square next time I visit the folder. This is why I think it is a common thing across the Win10 platform. My email account is a pop.Mail account.

content: I resolved my issue by deleting the affected folder (Inbox) and then creating a new Inbox folder in Settings. I was unable to move the messages in the affected Inbox folder to Archives and so 10 months of messages were lost. Going forward I am going to try to save messages to Archives on a more regular basis. I have a POP mail account.
creator: gassajl

content:
gassajl said
I resolved my issue by deleting the affected folder (Inbox) and then creating a new Inbox folder in Settings.

If you delete the two Inbox files in the profile, under the relevant account when TB isn't open, it will regenerate an Inbox of its own accord. This works for Trash, as well. Personal folders, however, do not regenerate. As david says, if an IMAP account, the folder will be repopulated. Not so if it's a POP3 account.

However, regular back up of your profiles to an external source away from the computer is always advantageous as it means recovery is possible not just if there is a problem with TB.
creator: frisée

content: My suggestion is to unsubscribe from both Important and AllMail. These are folders maintained by Google. The Allmail is a duplicate of your other folders (such as inbox, sent, trash, etc) and the Important folders is an ADDITIONAL duplicate. The Mozilla recommendation is to unsubscribe from both unless you have specific needs. First, they significantly increase your PC storage use, and they virtually double all incoming and outgoing messages, as Thunderbird must update each individually. After unsubscribing, I suggest exiting Thunderbird and deleting remaining folders from profile to eliminate the unwanted disk use.
creator: davidsk

content: To unsubscribe, highlight the account on main screen, rightclick and select 'subscribe' and then untick the folders.
creator: davidsk

content:
That was it! Thanks very much! I unsubscribed the Gmail All Mail and Important Mail. I suppose I thought that was a Thunderbird feature but wondered why. They were all duplicates-- and a Gmail feature.

The weirder thing was that it only started doing that recently, immediately when T-Bird updated to this new version 128.2.0esr, and not for the past 20 years of other T-Bird versions. I thought it may have had to refresh the mail folders or something for the newer version and would stop at some point. Maybe there's some glitches that are in the newer version that may work out over time?
creator: jtposey2

content: The challenge you face is that the email content must be fully formed prior to Thunderbird sending it. That reformatting would need to be done by an external process. An option might be to create multiple identities, each with a different quote, and pick one as desired.
creator: davidsk

content:
David thanks for the follow-up. Can you share more details about what you're suggesting?

Jeffrey
creator: jeffrey13iap

content:
To my knowledge, all options require work, some much more than others. The easiest that I know of is to create multiple identities, each with different quotes. To do that:

  1. click account settings and highlight the desired account
  2. on account pane, click 'manage identities'
  3. add an alternate identity, changing name slightly to ensure uniqueness, keep same email address but a different sig

Now, when selecting 'new message, the FROM drop-dowm will alllow choice of from address.

Another option, possibly easier, is to use the 'signature switch' addon.
creator: davidsk
